comments.commentBody:
"Religion has nothing to do with my workplace so I shouldn't even know what your religion is."

If a religion requires a head-scarf or turban or diet restriction of vegetarian food, how does that not come up in a workplace? Should the person hide their religion so that you do not get upset about it? Even if you own your workplace, these are things you have to deal with when it comes to hiring and managing employees.

It isn't about people making it a point of letting other know, it is how they live their life. A lot of religious aspects affect everyday life, many followers can't just leave their religion at home.

Well I walk around calling attention to the color of my skin, will you judge me for this then. The color of skin calls attention to the food I eat, the music I listen, to the friends I might have, you want to judge me on this? Or can you separate the color of my skin from the garments I am wearing?

I just don't have any sympathy for anyone who walks around the workplace calling attention to any personal beliefs-religion included.  Do you really think that human beings aren't going to judge you based on this?  Dream on.  Religion has nothing to do with my workplace so I shouldn't even know what your religion is.  If you want to make a point of letting people know, then accept the consequences.
"Fox News did not make Mr. O’Reilly or Mr. Ailes available for this article." This more or less sums it up for me: NY Times wants to talk to a supposed journalist and does not get access.
I imagine that the fictional Mel Goldberg would look a lot like Justice Kagan.

"In the photo above ..."

She is wearing black leggings ...
Nothing about A&F, their clothing, even their bags, denotes modesty!

Now that I've looked more closely at the photo of Ms. Elauf, I am more skeptical about the sincerity of this law suit. She says "I wear a head scarf, which is a symbol of modesty in my Muslim faith"

In the photo above, she wears a hijab -- and what appears to be, if not a mini skirt, certainly a garment which wouldn't pass the modesty test for either Muslims or orthodox Jewish women.

In fact, no Abercrombie store I've ever seen would pass the test either.
Which branch of the government do you think should be charged with determining which elements of your faith are worthy of protection by law, and which are not?

The FOX business plan is an old one, tell a big enough lie, often enough and the masses will believe it.  It is called faith and taps into a strong human need.  Facts or integrity have nothing to do with their modus operandi.

In the US there is a legal distinction between discrimination based on religion and discrimination based on other qualities, like obesity.  Freedom of religion has a very high level of protection. I think even higher than privacy.

Saying "liberals are decent people" is as rather sad and as biased as saying republicans are decent people; implying that the other party is not decent is closed-minded and sounds like something Mr. O'Reilly would say while flailing about trying to discredit opposing opinions.
That happens to me *all the time.* I get the feeling that sometimes comments critical of the Times or of the author are held for longer than those singing hosannas

NJot true. There is no comment section on many articles, including a fair number of Editorials and op-eds (though not those of Times columnists). And in news articles, no comments is the rule rather than the exception.

Mr. Etim: Why is it that, in August, 2013, the moderation staff was described (by you in this very journal) thus:
"The picks are made by a staff of about 13 mostly part-time moderators, all of whom are journalists, he said, and reviewed by a supervisor to make sure that 'there is a good mix of views.'"
http://publiceditor.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/08/02/perfectly-reasonable-qu...
Have the moderators gone to full time status? If not, why not. And how many are full time, and how many are part time?

.
@ Sam:

I've had limericks accepted for publication online. Sometimes, they get 100s of "recommends". If that has earned me a white checkmark, no one has informed me.

(Apologies for disagreeing w/you about color. You see green, I see white, and neither of us will be blessed with one so it matters little.)

(HEY! Was that a crack about people who write limericks?!?)
You're attacking the attackers? Shouldn't the truth be valued in and of itself no matter who the mouth belonged to? Surely the truth has some actual value.

Looking forward to our next adventure. Our careers have been an odyssey of our times, both good and bad. But, now its time for us to live off our wits.  At this phase in life a couple of nomadic years sounds great.

You are missing the point.  This case is about religious discrimination in employment, which is expressly forbidden by the Civil Rights Act of 1965.  The Act does not, however, prohibit discriminating against people like you who act or dress "weird."
They haven't ruled yet Amber.

"... made freedom of speech an uncompromising overarching principle."

This wasn't a freedom of speech case. It was a religious accommodation case under 42 U.S.C. §§ 2000e to 2000e-17.

See the appeals court ruling:
http://sblog.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/10th-cir-11-511...

See also:
42 U.S. Code Chapter 21, Subchapter VI - EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES
https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/42/chapter-21/subchapter-VI

If I pay you and you represent my company I care how you look.  I don't want you with nose rings, tattoos or hajibs.  I consider those looks would harm my business image, Why do you have to force your religious observances on me?
You did not answer the question Counter Measures.  I suspect you won't answer it in detail.

Mr. Rao's post misses the point that The Nation does not pretend to be "fair and balanced." It has been a proud flagship of avowedly liberal opinion for decades. Fox, on the other hand, practices a disgraceful kind of hypocrisy in refusing to own up to its role as a propaganda organ for the the right. Why are they afraid to say what they stand for? And in the case of Sarah L., they apparently have viewers who are not aware that the "fair and balanced" line is a hoax.

Mr. Rao also misses the point that releasing a video of Mitt Romney saying things that torpedoed his campaign does not involve lying on Mr. Corn's part; it also ignore the crucial detail that it is O'Reilly who has been caught (yet again) lying outrageously, not David Corn. David Corn may have his hair on fire for liberalism, but Mitt Romney is still an arrogant fool who shot himself in the foot, and Bill O'Reilly is still a self-aggrandizing, whopper-spinning fraud. The upshot is, Mr. Rao's comment is a complete non-sequitir.
As the article says, it was AFkids, not Abercrombie & Fitch. Not so sexy.
Moray is an eel.  Mores is what you are searching for.

It's a legitimate concern, but fortunately there is an exception to the religious accommodation requirement to the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

"Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibits employment discrimination based on religion. This includes refusing to accommodate an employee's sincerely held religious beliefs or practices unless the accommodation would impose an undue hardship (more than a minimal burden on operation of the business)." http://www.eeoc.gov/eeoc/newsroom/wysk/workplace_religious_accommodation...

Having an employee wear a hijab at Abercrombie is pretty "minimal" to me. (In fact, I've seen some strikingly beautiful hijabs). A burka probably would not be. (Not that I qualify as a labor lawyer).
What if she wanted to make a point just like this young lady and her lawyers?

Mr. Dantes, I think the answer to your question is that Fox does not represent a "non-liberal" slant to the news. It represents an over-the-cliff proganda position in favor of the right. Fox is not afraid to repeat completely debunked nonsense about fake scandals like Benghazi in order to keep up the attacks on Democratic politicians, and to pump up it's ill-informed audience's outrage. Fox is so persistent in repeating obvious non-truths that they are responsible for the charming recent colloquialism, "zombie lie", used for lies that just won't die.

Let me also add another reason that the Times does not follow Fox down the rabbit hole: although making a profit is certainly essential to the New York Times, it is essential to the Times that it do so by actually reporting the news. Evidently you think that the news business is just a bunch of clowns out to do nothing beyond making a buck, a blundering act of cynicism which is not surprising for a Fox supporter.
